LDAP groups: groupOfUniqueNames or posixGroup
entry.content:
When deciding what type of groups to be implemented in the LDAP directory must consider what will be the main task of them, for example:
  • Reflect the structure of an organization.
  • To manage system groups.
In the first case will require the flexibility provided by nested groups, where they can establish a hierarchy, for example, could serve to inherit characteristics of the higher groups. The groupOfUniqueNames ojectClass is recommended.  Multivalued attribute uniqueMember  may list the entry's DN of users and groups that form it.

In the second case, where you want to use LDAP to manage groups of a system based on the POSIX standard, such as most Linux distributions, are available on posixGroup objectClass, which implements the features of such groups as the attribute gidNumber, which stores the numeric identifier that is used internally by POSIX systems. In memberUid multi-valued attribute specifies the uids of the entries that belong to the group. The POSIX standard does not provide for nesting of groups.

entry.title: LUMA (II)
NextFreeUnixID: Managing unique numeric identifiers
entry.content:
In the management of accounts of system, either users or groups, are very important the numerical identifiers, since these are handled internally that the system to uniquely identify each item, for example, in POSIX systems. In LDAP, these identifiers correspond to the attributes uidNumber for users and gidNumber for groups. In LDAP is not available an automatic method of assigning these codes, so that the operator or applications have the task to finding a code available. The solution is to enable a place in the directory itself as a counter to these attributes, so that you can store the value of the next available code to retrieve and update it when inserting new users or groups. This creates an entry similar to the following:


dn: cn=nextFreeUnixId,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
cn: NextFreeUnixID
gidNumber: 1001
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: sambaUnixIdPool
objectClass: top
sn: NextFreeUnixID
uidNumber: 10017

As shown, this entry uses sambaUnixIdPool the object class contained in the scheme of Samba, whose installation is explained in the previous article: Extending directory schema: including SAMBA schema

nextFreeUnixId.ldif File.


# ldapadd -H "ldap://dir01.ldapconfig.net" -f "nextFreeUnixId.ldif" - D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W


When you go to register a new user or group account, will take the value of the respective counter (uidNumber for users and gidNumber for groups), with the caveat previously update this entry nextFreeUnixId to the new counter value will be free. This must be done well because if you try to add new entries with the current counter values​​, will not allow it to fail because of duplicate values.

In this example we have decided to place the entry nextFreeUnixId at the top level directory, but that it would be possible to define an entry nextFreeUnixId in every department if they want to make a particular numbering branch.

entry.title: Extending directory schema: including SAMBA schema
entry.content:
The scheme of data types that can support an LDAP directory is fully configurable and extensible so that we can cover a wide range of needs. The specifications of object classes, attributes, syntax and rules are defined in files with .schema . In versions prior to 2.3, the inclusion of these files is done directly by reference to these files through include clause in the configuration file slapd.conf, then restarting the service for taking changes.


include /etc/ldap/schema/samba.schema

However, modern versions of OpenLDAP use dynamic management of configuration through cn=config directory, and is necessary to transform these files from .schema to .lidf format to be loaded into the configuration directory.


To explain the conversion process from schema file to Ldif format and later load in the configuration directory, we will add the SAMBA schema, which we will use in subsequent articles.

  • First, It is first necessary get the file samba.schema. In Linux, this file is included in the package samba-doc.

    # sudo aptitude install samba-doc
  • After installing the package, locate the file samba.schema.gz into /usr/share/doc/samba-doc/examples/LDAP directory. We copy to ldap configuration directory and unpack it:

    # sudo cp /usr/share/doc/samba-doc/examples/LDAP/samba.schema.gz /etc/ldap/schema/

    # sudo gzip -d /etc/ldap/schema/samba.schema.gz
  • If the OpenLDAP configuration system is the slapd.conf file, only we need to include the line, as noted above ...

    /etc/ldap/slapd.conf

    include /etc/ldap/schema/samba.schema

    And restart service...


    /etc/init.d/slapd restart
    And the schema already would be available.
  • If the configuration system is using the cn=config directory, then we must do the following steps:
    1. Into the /etc/ldap/schema/ directory, create a file schema_convert.conf that specifies all schema files that implements the directory, with the following structure:

      include /etc/ldap/schema/core.schema
      include /etc/ldap/schema/cosine.schema
      include /etc/ldap/schema/nis.schema
      include /etc/ldap/schema/inetorgperson.schema
      include /etc/ldap/schema/samba.schema
      ...
      The supported schemas are in /etc/ldap/slapd.d/cn=config/cn=schema directory. When specifying the file schema_convert.conf is necessary to respect the order given in braces {}
    2. Enable a temporary directory to hold the results of the .ldif format conversion.

      # mkdir /tmp/ldif_output/
    3. Conversion from .schema files to .ldif

      # slapcat -f "/etc/ldap/schema/schema_convert.conf" -F "/tmp/ldif_output" -n0 -s "cn={4}samba,cn=schema,cn=config" > /tmp/ldif_output/cn=samba.ldif
      In -s option, note the index between braces {}, starting from 0, referencing to the schema we want to convert.
    4. Edit the /tmp/cn\=samba.ldif generated LDIF file:
      • Change the value of the following attributes:

        dn: cn=samba,cn=schema,cn=config
        ...
        cn: samba
      • Eliminate system's internal attributes, located at end of file:
        • structuralObjectClass
        • entryUUID
        • creatorsName
        • createTimestamp
        • entryCSN
        • modifiersName
        • modifyTimestamp
    5. Add the new schema:

      # sudo ldapadd -Y EXTERNAL -H "ldapi:///" -f "/tmp/ldif_output/cn\=samba.ldif"

Reference: Ubuntu Documentation: OpenLDAP Server

link.title: Extending directory schema: including SAMBA schema

entry.title: Python Script to generate LDIF files to add users massively
entry.content:
A simple example of the ease and usefulness of the LDIF file handling is the sample script we're going to see today's article. We will see an automated process of creating an LDIF file that can serve to add several users together, whose data were stored in a csv file. In this exercise also includes a method for generating random passwords, which are dumped in clear text to an output file and check of duplicate IDs on the directory that if any be reported in a log file.


  • newUsers.csv It is a csv file format that allows us to enter the relevant data of the users, represented as a table where the columns are separated by a semicolon (;) and rows by a newline.

    Columns:
    1. Name
    2. Surname
    3. uid
    4. Department
    Richard;Moore;richard.moore;trade
    Susan;Taylor;susan.taylor;trade
    James;Smith;james.smith;tech
    Joseph;Thomas;joseph.thomas;tech
    Margaret;Jackson;margaret.jackson;tech
  • generateUsersLDIF.py Is the script written in Python and requires the following parameters:
    • -h --help A description of the function of the script with the options available.
    • -s --serverLDAP Specifies the name or IP address of the LDAP server on which load the LDIF file to generate. Default: localhost.
    • -b --baseDN LDAP suffix. Default: dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    • -u --uidNumberInit First uidNumber available from which new entries are numbered. Default: 101
  • users.ldif It is the resulting LDIF file format and ready for loading on directory.
  • users.csv This file contains the data of the user along with your password in clear.

    SURNAME;NAME;UID;PASSWORD

    Moore;Richard;richard.moore;9!7XC!Su

    Taylor;Susan;susan.taylor;Gf3l2w#J

    Thomas;Joseph;joseph.thomas;jqNMGG2@

    Jackson;Margaret;margaret.jackson;BPLYiu7b

  • users.log Record any incidents occurred in the LDIF file generation. In this version, only checks that the attribute uid does not already exist in the directory. When exists, there not generate LDIF entry and include the notice in this file.

    UID;CAUSE

    james.smith;Account already exists



In our example, the script is launched:


./generateUsersLDIF.py --fileIn "newUsers.csv" --serverLDAP "dir01.ldapconfig.net" --baseDN "dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" --uidNumberInit 10013


Note that the user james.smith already exists in the directory, but is in a different department, and therefore their input is not included in the LDIF file.

The LDIF file generated is fully operational to be loaded into the directory with the ldapadd command.


$ ldapadd -H "ldap://dir01.ldapconfig.net" -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W -f "users.ldif"

link.title: Python Script to generate LDIF files to add users massively

entry.title: OpenLDAP lab: Modifying a directory (II)
entry.content:
In today's article will discuss the modification and deletion of attributes of an entry and how to delete a directory entry.

  • Changing an admin user group of the branch "tech". Replacing jennifer.anderson for david.martinez.
  • "Management" branch; moving james.smith from managers group to secretaries group.
    • Creating modifyGroups.ldif file:

      dn: cn=admins,ou=groups,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      changetype: modify
      replace: uniqueMember
      uniqueMember: uid=david.martinez,ou=users,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: cn=managers,ou=groups,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      changetype: modify
      delete: uniqueMember
      uniqueMember: uid=james.smith,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: cn=secretaries,ou=groups,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      changetype: modify
      add: uniqueMember
      uniqueMember: uid=james.smith,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net



      $ ldapmodify -H "ldap://localhost" -f "modifyGroups.ldif" -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W
  • Deleting john.williams user...

    $ ldapdelete -H "ldap://localhost" -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W "uid=john.williams,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net"

    The john.williams user belongs to secretaries group even after being deleted from directory.

    $ ldapsearch -x -b "cn=secretaries,ou=groups,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -LLL


    dn: cn=secretaries,ou=groups,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames
    cn: secretaries
    uniqueMember: uid=john.williams,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    uniqueMember: uid=patricia.brown,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    uniqueMember: uid=james.smith,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

    Referential integrity is not respected by default, thus far, be maintained manually using modifySecretariesGroup.ldif file.


    modifySecretariesGroup.ldif

    dn: cn=secretaries,ou=groups,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    changetype: modify
    delete: uniqueMember
    uniqueMember: uid=john.williams,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net



    $ ldapmodify -H "ldap://localhost" -f "modifySecretariesGroup.ldif" -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W

entry.title: OpenLDAP lab: Modifying a directory (I)
entry.content:
In the previous article we saw steps to create a directory and upload content (organization, departments, users and user groups), through an LDIF file and corresponding LDAP command : ldapadd. In today's entry and the next, we will follow that line basically, using the same tools to make changes in the data that are already in that directory.

  • Backup: Making a backup previous to data manipulation operations is always a  a good idea. Could use Slapcat command:

    $ slapcat>backup1.ldif

    Looking at the resulting LDIF that extends to the original used to create it, because it includes some control attributes.


    backup1.ldif
    sstructure.ldif
    ...


    dn: ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    objectClass: organizationalUnit
    ou: management
    description: management department
    structuralObjectClass: organizationalUnit
    entryUUID: a7247474-a0a7-1030-93e8-015c48fd7d20
    creatorsName: cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    createTimestamp: 20111111115428Z
    entryCSN: 20111111115428.127800Z#000000#000#000000
    modifiersName: cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    modifyTimestamp: 20111111115428Z


    ...    		 ...


    dn: ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
    objectClass: organizationalUnit
    ou: management
    description: management department


    ...

  • Adding a password attribute to user entries
    1. Create the LDIF file from a search for user entries, which are those with the object Class inetOrgPerson. The -LLL option ignore the comments and results aggregation labels.


      $ ldapsearch -x -b "dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -LLL "(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)" dn > addPassword.ldif


      addPassword.ldif

      dn: uid=james.smith,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=mary.johnson,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=john.williams,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=patricia.brown,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=robert.jones,ou=users,ou=trade,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=linda.miller,ou=users,ou=trade,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=michael.davis,ou=users,ou=trade,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=barbara.garcia,ou=users,ou=trade,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=william.rodriguez,ou=users,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=elizabeth.wilson,ou=users,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=david.martinez,ou=users,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

      dn: uid=jennifer.anderson,ou=users,ou=tech,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net

    2. We will include an encrypted default password for all users.

      $ slappasswd -h {SSHA} -s 123
      {SSHA}p89ZqS84y1mBzZw0f9mHKFOuUHdc9h1v
    3. The resulting encrypted string is added to the LDIF file for each entry along with the directive that indicates the inclusion of the new field:

      dn: uid=james.smith,ou=users,ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      add: userPassword
      usrPassword: {SSHA}p89ZqS84y1mBzZw0f9mHKFOuUHdc9h1v


      Full LDIF file:  addPassword.ldif

    4. The userPassword attribute is confidential info for the LDAP server and therefore, will only appear in authenticated administrator searchs.


      $ ldapsearch -x -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W -b "dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" "(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)"

entry.title: OpenLDAP lab: Backups
entry.content:
As soon as the directory be configured and contains data, is a good time to think how to make backups.

  • SAVING...
    1. Stop LDAP service:

      $ /etc/init.d/slapd stop
    2. Save the configuration directory:

      $ cp -R /etc/ldap backup/
    3. Save data

      $ slapcat -b "base_dn" > backup/data.ldif
    4. Start LDAP service:

      $ /etc/init.d/slapd start
  • RESTORING...
    1. Stop LDAP service:

      $ /etc/init.d/slapd stop
    2. Delete database's old files (if applicable). The slapadd command requires to make the restoration in an empty database.
      If HDB database (Berkeley)

      $ rm /var/lib/ldap/__db.*
    3. Restore settings:

      $ cp -R backup/ldap /etc/
    4. Restore data:

      $ slapadd -b "base_dn" -l "backup/data.ldif"
    5. Start LDAP service:

      $ /etc/init.d/slapd start
  • ISSUES
    • It is very important stop the service to make copies, restoration and management of database files, thus avoiding potential corruption problems and inconsistencies in the database.
    • The slapadd and slapcat commands allow to manage the directory data operating directly on the database.
    • LDIF files obtained by the command slapcat not have to respect the directory hierarchy, and that the ordering is given by the position of their records in the database. They also include internal control attributes of the server. Therefore, they are not suited to be used by tools that operate on-line with the service, such as ldapadd, and ldapmodify.
      Looking at the resulting LDIF that extends to the original check that was used to create it, because it includes some control attributes. These fields are hidden in regular search results.



      data.ldif
      structure.ldif
      ...


      dn: ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      objectClass: organizationalUnit
      ou: management
      description: management department
      structuralObjectClass: organizationalUnit
      entryUUID: a7247474-a0a7-1030-93e8-015c48fd7d20
      creatorsName: cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      createTimestamp: 20111111115428Z
      entryCSN: 20111111115428.127800Z#000000#000#000000
      modifiersName: cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      modifyTimestamp: 20111111115428Z


      ...      		 ...


      dn: ou=management,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
      objectClass: organizationalUnit
      ou: management
      description: management department


      ...


    • Probable error:


      This may appear when trying to overwrite an existing database using slapadd command . To fix this, run the step 2 of paragraph Restoring....

entry.title: OpenLDAP lab: Creating a directory
entry.content:
We will work on a practical example of what has been discussed in previous articles. We will deploy, using OpenLDAP, a LDAP directory of an organization known as ldapconfig.net. Will be divided into three departments: Management, Trade and Technical, that will contain information about users and user groups.

To storing all this structure and information within the directory are necessary to examine the datatypes and decide what types of objects and LDAP attributes are appropriate to implement them.


To help, consult a viewer classes and attributes, such as akbkhome.

Assuming the installation and subsequent configuration indicated in the previous post "OpenLDAP installation", the directory was create with your domain component (root directory). it can check, for example, by the ldapsearch command:


$ ldapsearch -x -b "dc=ldapconfig,dc=net"

Resulting a LDIF output with two entries: the domain component (root directory) ldapconfig.net  and the admin user:


# extended LDIF
#
# LDAPv3
# base dc=ldapconfig,dc=net with scope subtree
# filter: (objectclass=*)
# requesting: ALL
#

# ldapconfig.net
dn: dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
objectClass: top
objectClass: dcObject
objectClass: organization
o: ldapconfig.net
dc: ldapconfig

# admin, ldapconfig.net
dn: cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net
objectClass: simpleSecurityObject
objectClass: organizationalRole
cn: admin
description: LDAP administrator

# search result
search: 2
result: 0 Success

# numResponses: 3
# numEntries: 2

Later, the reverse operation: a LDIF file will be used to write to the designed directory structure. The LDIF file example: structure.ldif


$ ldapadd -D "cn=admin,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net" -W -H "ldap://localhost" -f "structure.ldif"

The ldapadd command launches a write operation over the ldapconfig.net directory, building structure contained in the file estructura.ldif. It must done with a user with write permissions, in this case the admin user, indicated by -D option, and entering its password in interactive mode, indicated by -W. With -H option indicates the LDAP server URI, therefore, this operation can be launched remotely from an LDAP client.

entry.title: LDIF format
entry.content:
The LDIF format provides the necessary syntax for information interchange with a LDAP service: return query results and specification of write operations on a directory, and more... It is supported by the commands that interact directly with the LDAP service and may contain descriptions of both data and directory settings, along with directives that indicate actions to be executed. Standard is documented by RFC2849.
LDIF files are sequential plain text, which gives advantages such as being read and modified directly by the people and make processing easier through simple script programming.
The uses of LDIF files are multiple: safeguards and replacement of data, save query results, charges and massive changes, migration ... Are directly used by the LDAP commands:

ldapsearch
Searchs.
ldapadd
Adds.
ldapdelete
Deletes.
ldapmodify
Modifies.
ldapmodifyrdn
RDN Modifies.

General rules:
  1. Comments: Comments lines begin by #

  2. Lines.: can split lines with a carriage return and continue to the next line add a space at the beginning.
  3. Non ASCII characters: will be encoded in base64.
  4. Format of entries: 
    1. Must to comply the directory schema: Declaration of classes of objects, compulsory attributes, hierarchy, unique values ​​in the attributes that require it ...
    2. Separation between entries. By at least one blank line.
    3. Distinguished Name or DN Heading each entry.
      • dn: string_dn_entry
      • May be formed by one or more attributes. When is formed by more than one attribute:
        1. Uses operator +.
        2. Delete spaces around =.
        3. Escape special characters.
        4. Delete non escaped spaces around multivalued RDN.
    4. Atributtes Attributes are specified by pattern:
      attribute_name: attribute_value

      In case of multivalued attributes, different values should be placed consecutively.


  5. Modifying attributes To modify the information stored in the directory is necessary to include a series of directives in the LDIF file, which will become subsequently treated with the command ldapmodify.



In subsequent blog entries will be extended and extensive examples of this format and its applications.

entry.title: Uninstalling OpenLDAP compiled from de sources files
entry.content:
Generally, and whenever possible, it is best make an installation from repository package, this provides a more clean and complete installation (including scripts start / stop the default option files ...) Still, installations by compiling sources  are often found. In version 2.4, yet inexplicably not included the possibility of launching the uninstall process via command:

$ make uninstall

instead it is necessary to perform the deletion of files manually, for which the process is as follows:

  1. Stop LDAP service
    $ pkill slapd
  2. Clean, if you have not done before, the temporary files automatically generated during the build process (core files, dependencies, makefiles, ...)
    $(compilation directory) make veryclean
  3. Clean manually files (taking the installation directory base)
    • bin/
      • ldapadd
      • ldapcompare
      • ldapdelete
      • ldapexop
      • ldapmodify
      • ldapmodrdn
      • ldappasswd
      • ldapsearch
      • ldapuri
      • ldapwhoami
    • etc/
      • openldap
    • include/
      • lber.h
      • lber_types.h
      • ldap_cdefs.h
      • ldap_features.h
      • ldap.h
      • ldap_schema.h
      • ldap_utf8.h
      • slapi-plugin.h
    • lib/
      • liblber-VERSION.so.2
      • liblber-VERSION.so.2.5.6
      • liblber.a
      • liblber.la
      • liblber.so
      • libldap-VERSION.so.2
      • libldap-VERSION.so.2.5.6
      • libldap.a
      • libldap.la
      • libldap_r-VERSION.so.2
      • libldap_r-VERSION.so.2.5.6
      • libldap_r.a
      • libldap_r.la
      • libldap_r.so
      • libldap.so
    • libexec/
      • slapd
    • sbin/
      • slapacl
      • slapadd
      • slapauth
      • slapcat
      • slapdn
      • slapindex
      • slappasswd
      • slapschema
      • slaptest
    • share/man/
      • man1/
        • ldap*.*
      • man3/

        • slapschema.8
        • slaptest.8

      • run/
        • slapd.args
        • slapd.pid

entry.title: Encrypting passwords
entry.content:
Use encrypted passwords is a good idea, even in config files. Both in the slapd.conf configuration file as the directory cn = config, rootpw directive defines the OpenLDAP administrator's password, so it is highly recommended to protect this sensitive data encoded with some encryption algorithm, such as SSHA. To generate the encrypted string with a password, use the command slappasswd:


$ slappasswd -h {método_encriptación} -s contraseña

Example:

$ slappasswd -h {SSHA} -s secreto

{SSHA}F+glgnMPxE998ufWhOlQr+GrDC1CUjA5aUpxNU5XVkE5aTlj

The generated string must be specified in rootpw directive


rootpw {SSHA}F+glgnMPxE998ufWhOlQr+GrDC1CUjA5aUpxNU5XVkE5aTlj

entry.title: No DB_CONFIG file found in directory
entry.content:
This is one of the possible incidents that may occur immediately after the installation process, especially in the compilation of source files, when trying to boot the server.
bdb_db_open: warning - no DB_CONFIG file found in directory /usr/local/var/openldap-data: (2).
The solution is as easy as renaming the example file that usually comes in the specified directory, where database files are stored.

$ cp /usr/local/var/openldap-data/DB_CONFIG.example /usr/local/var/openldap-data/DB_CONFIG

link.title: No DB_CONFIG file found in directory

entry.title: OpenLDAP installation
entry.content:
How to get OpenLDAP

  1. From the official website openldap.org you can download the source files that later must compile to proceed to installation.
  2. Through the package repositories the different Linux distributions. The package is often called slapd.
Source files compilation
If you choose to download the source files, you must follow these steps:
  1. Unpack
    $ gunzip -c openldap-VERSION.tgz | tar xvfB -
  2. Run configure. You must know the next steps require several tools (such as gawk, gcc, make ...)  installed on the system for enable the compilation and installation.
    $ ./configure
  3. Compile

    $ make depend
    $ make
  4. Check

    $ make test
  5. Install software. The default directory which is to be installed is /usr/local. If we want a different one, we must specify in step 4, when compiling.

    $ su root -c 'make install'
  6. If you choose to use Berkeley database as data repository (recommended), you will need to install it.
    • libdbVERSION
    • libdbVERSION-dev
  7. Basic Setup. Edit the slapd.conf configuration file which is usually located at /etc/ldap/ or /usr/local/etc/openldap

    database hdb
    suffix "dc=ldapconfig,dc=net"
    rootdn "cn=Manager,dc=ldapconfig,dc=net"
    rootpw secret
    directory /usr/local/var/openldap-data
  8. Check. Whenever you edit a configuration file there is the possibility of errors. OpenLDAP offers the possibility of a configuration check using the command:

    $ slaptest
  9. server startup.

    $ su root -c /usr/local/libexec/slapd
  10. Test. One possible method to ascertain if the server is working properly is to launch a search.

    $ ldapsearch -x

    If everything works OK ...


    # extended LDIF
    #
    # LDAPv3
    # base <> (default) with scope subtree
    # filter: (objectclass=*)
    # requesting: ALL
    #

    # search result
    search: 2
    result: 32 No such object

    # numResponses: 1


Installing from a package repository
This method is most widespread among users, as it is easier to perform and has advantages such as ease of update, start and stop scripts, configuration wizard, etc ...

  1. Installing packages.

    $ aptitude install slapd openldap-utils
  2. Basic Setup. It can be done using a simple wizard.

    $ dpkg-reconfigure slapd
    • Omit OpenLDAP server configuration? No
    • DNS Domain Name: ldapdconfig.net
    • Name of your organization: ldapconfig
    • Admin password:
    • Confirm password:
    • Database: HDB
    • Do you want your database to be removed when slapd is purged? No
    • Move old database? Yes
    • Allow LDAPv2 protocol?
      • Yes
        • Only in justified cases for compatibility with older systems
      • No
        • Generally

entry.title: Names model
entry.content:
The names model describes how LDAP is solved the requirement to uniquely identify each of the entries. Each entry is associated with a Distinguished Name or DN, that is a reference (not an attribute) to the absolute path of the entry from the root. The Relative Distinguished Name, or RDN, is the distinguished name at the branch level, ie, the attribute or set of attributes that uniquely identifies the entry in its branch. So, we will to form the DN of an entry concatenating its RDN with the predecessor branch's DN. This way of building the DN has a drawback; if a branch entry is moved, its DN change too inevitably and that's also something to consider when it comes to reference it.

As another entry, the directory root is also mandatory to have a DN.  This root DN also will appear in the DNs of the all entries in the entire directory. Logically, the RDN and DN of the root are the same. The root DN may be known variously as Directory Name Context, context, suffix, or base DN. The root entry must be formed by an object class that has the domain attribute, or dc component. How determine its name has no fixed rule, but it is highly recommended to give the same DNS domain component. If our organization has a public Internet DNS, it's a good idea share it with LDAP, because both have the same philosophy of geographic distribution.

entry.title: Information model
entry.content:
The information model describes how the logical structure of the directory information. The arrangement involves a hierarchy tree whose most important node is the root. Each node is a child of a single father and, in turn, may have one or more child nodes, which will form what is known as branches and sub-branches.


LDAP has its own terms to refer to the different elements that form a tree. The root is also known as base or suffix. Nodes are referred to as entries. The whole tree is known as DIT (Directory Information Tree) or directory tree. Organize the information in this way offers the advantage of being an intuitive format, adapted to the distributed scheme and very documented and disseminated in the world of computing.
Perhaps as a drawback could say that clashes with the concept of relational databases conventional.

In LDAP tree nodes are known as entries. Each entry describes an object using attributes that have one or more values​​, in this second case are called multivalued attributes. Attribute names are, most often, by nature of their mnemonic names in English.


The attributes of an entry depend on its object classes . An object class is just a formal definition of attribute names, data type that can host and whether they are required or optional for those objects that use the class. The object classes group attributes that refer to characteristics of the same nature (personal data, authentication systems, email, ...)

Object classes are usually dynamically loaded into the LDAP server using files with .Schema extension. The set of objects classes  that are instances by the LDAP server is called a directory schema. Thus, this directory schema may be easily directory extended with new functionality as needs arise.

This example entry stores input data from a user of an information system. First, instance the inetOrgPerson object class allows to access personal data attributes, such as first name and surname Secondly, posixAccount object class with the system attributes, such as home directory and user IDs.

entry.title: Why LDAP / OpenLDAP?
entry.content:
Among the main features that can help us decide to use an LDAP service implementation are:

  1. Dynamic
    • LDAP operations are performed in real time. The LDAP server uses threads so it can serve requests in parallel.
    • LDAP is optimized for search operations.
  2. Safe
    • Allows setting to require authentication to use their services.
    • You can manage which users or types of users can access certain information and what types of operations they can do about it.
    • Uses standard libraries TLS / SSL for encrypted transmission mechanisms.
  3. Flexible
    • Supports multiple separate directories.
    • Supports many configuration options that are easily adapted to any setting.
    • Accepts dynamic modification settings. So simple and no impact to the service.
    • Allows to store all kinds of information.
    • Hierarchical storage.
    • It offers powerful search filters.
  4. Extensible
    • You can define own schemes if the existing data do not cover the needs.
    • Specially designed to work in distributed systems, providing customers a unique service vision, while optimizing their access regardless of geographic location.
    • Allows data replication between servers (simple and inexpensive), increasing efficiency in distributed environments.
  5. Standard
    • It is independent of any manufacturer.
    • Its specifications are public and freely available.
    • Client-server abstraction. LDAP commands will always be the same regardless of the LDAP implementation we use.
    • Easy integration with applications.
    • Available development libraries for most programming languages.
  6. Simple
    • Installation.
    • Optimization.
    • Maintenance.
Currently available products that implement multiple LDAP servers, most of them adapted to support for other products (eg saving configurations, user management, authentication, etc ...)
This catalog can be classified basically as platform or operating system and operating license under which they are available (proprietary or free)

A very important factor in which we look is compatible with the LDAP standard, especially in relation to replicate with other implementations.


The choice is based on factors as quality: it is a consolidated project born from the original project which resulted in the protocol, version 3 supports with a large number of directory schemes, which will make possible to cover a broad spectrum of data types store. It is fully compatible with the LDAP standard and provides the architecture of distributed and replicated. Finally, you have free license and the source code is accessible, which gives the assurance that could be adapted to any circumstance.

entry.title: How does LDAP work?
entry.content:
The RFC2251 documentation, which defines the LDAP protocol, proposes two abstract models to describe the services to be provided by an LDAP server. This proposal covers LDAP from two aspects: the protocol and storage. The concept of both models is clearly evident in the way that LDAP is sometimes referred to in common parlance. It is very common to use statements like the following:

"Users are stored in LDAP", or "The application gets the permissions via LDAP". Both are correct and each is set at a different view of the service. The first refers to LDAP as a repository of information, the second focuses on LDAP as a tool to manage that information.


In the graph we also see that LDAP adopts client - server model. Following the division, we can say that the client makes requests asynchronously (the client may send requests without waiting for the previous response from the server, and it will respond to requests in any order) to the LDAP server knows that accesses data stored in a repository, but completely unknown what type storage supports it (relational database, text file ...) This is possible regardless of the type that the client always use the same management tools and is the LDAP service you have to "translate" those requests to specific instructions to carry them in the particular system that implements storage. Ultimately, the customer will be only necessary to know the LDAP commands. For the LDAP server administrator, they know what kind of storage supports LDAP, so you may need to specify in the configuration of it, but little else. If the information is stored in a relational database, the LDAP administrator will need to know anything about the tables, relations and other uses, of all the LDAP service will. The administrator's role will focus on seeking to provide the best service, focusing on resource optimization, secure access, data definition, etc ...

Operations:
  • StartTLS Uses the Transport Layer Security (TLS) LDAPv3 extension for secure connection.
  • bind Authenticates and specifies LDAP protocol version.
  • search seeks and obtains directory entries.
  • compare Tests if a named entry contains a given attribute value.
  • add Adds new entry.
  • delete Deletes an entry.
  • modify Modifies an entry.
  • modify distinguished name (DN) Renames an entry.
  • abandon Cancels a previous request.
  • extended operation Generic operation used to define other operations.
  • unbind closes the connection (not the inverse of Bind)
Exceptionally, the server can send unsolicited notifications, for example, a warning of exhaustion of connection timeout.


In addition to the theoretical models presented in the RFC2251 (protocol model and data model), another widespread models describing LDAP from the following:
  • Information model. Describes how information is organized logically. This structure is a tree. 
  • Names model. Sets the rules for naming the objects that make up the structure of information, allowing identification of a unique denomination.
  • Functional model. Focuses on the operational and describing the repertoire of operations available for the treatment of information.
  • Security model. refers to the mechanisms of protecting and managing access to information.

entry.title: LDAP uses
entry.content:
Taking the generic definition of the use of LDAP as a cataloging objects tool, and combine it with their main characteristics:

  • Configuration flexibility.
  • Searches optimized.
  • Security.
  • Open and extensible standard.


The result is that LDAP is a great platform to implement:

  • Managing users, groups, authentication, roaming profiles, settings ...
  • Network infrastructure, service integration link, resource access control, messaging ...
  • Security Digital Certificate: creation, distribution, destruction, location accessible to users ...
  • Information Management: Address Book, organization of corporations, cataloging resources ...
  • And more ...



Keep in mind the ease of operating as distributed and replicated system, makes it possible to extend from local systems to global, overcoming geographical limitations and optimizing resources.

By contrast, before deciding whether LDAP can be useful for our purposes, it should review some of its limitations:

  • It is not designed to interact directly with the end user. Therefore, most of the time, you need to develop an application or Web service that allows for such dialogue.
  • Information units must be reduced in size. We must not lose sight of the concept of light and it also implies that the objects to be managed are reduced in size.
  • LDAP is optimized for searching operations, against other write operations, therefore the information should be static in nature.
  • It isn't comparable to a relational database. Although LDAP provides storage along with the functions of management, is not comparable to the functions of a relational database, which includes features as transactions, referential integrity, SQL language ...

entry.title: A very brief history ...
entry.content:
The origin of LDAP protocol are found in the 1980's, when the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) defined the x.500 standard. Within specifications, as well as the concepts of scale and hierarchical structure, describing the various directory services protocols:


  • Directory Access (DAP).
  • System directory.
  • Hiding directory information.
  • Management operational links directory.

These protocols were based on the OSI model seven-layer stack of protocols. Additionally, in the 90's, a project of the University of Michigan proposed to implement an alternate version of DAP lighter on the family of TCP / IP, much simpler than the OSI model. This new implementation called LDBP (Lightweight Directory Browsing Protocol) as its role was limited to navigation and search functions within the directory. Later, as they were including write operations and information management, took the name of LDAP.

Currently the LDAP protocol has completely replaced its predecessor, thanks in part to the wide diffusion of the family of TCP / IP, providing it with greater understanding and implementation simplicity. Has reached maturity and strengthened its capacity expansion and strong development through OpenLDAP, an open source alternative emerged from the original project.

entry.title: What's LDAP?
entry.content:
The first step to get into LDAP will be defined, and what better way to do it by looking at the meaning of their acronym. LDAP, Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.

  • What is? It's an application protocol.
  • What's the use? To access directories.
  • Its most striking feature is... Lightweight.

LDAP is used to access directories. But, what is a directory? In the context of information technology, we can define a directory as a logical and hierarchical system (hardware + software + data) which allows the storage, cataloging and management objects based on attributes. Understanding the object as any kind of information. Within management operations include insert, modify and delete information, given that a directory is designed to support browsing and will be these that are more optimized.

A directory must be accessible under the best conditions for all users who need it, providing a fast and reliable global service. This should include the ability to deploy it in distributed environments and enable the content diffusion by replicas.

The acronym LDAP also refer to the main feature of this protocol: lightweight. The reason to qualify so that is implemented within the protocol stack TCP / IP - much more optimized than the OSI model - thus achieving the maximum minimize the resources needed for its operation. In addition, TCP / IP is much more widespread, is constantly evolving and is the cornerstone on which rests the Internet. LDAP also has less operations than X.500, because eliminating those of little use.


LDAP, as open standard protocol, has published its specifications in the following documents:

  • RFC3377  Technical Specification LDAP v3 protocol. Refers to the following documents:
    • RFC2251 Protocol specification.
    • RFC2252 Syntax of attributes.
    • RFC2253 Distinguished name.
    • RFC2254 Search filters.
    • RFC 2255 URL format.
    • RFC 2256 User Schema.
    • RFC 2829 Authentication.
    • RFC 2830 Extension for Transport Layer Security.

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
This blog was born after nearly five years working on LDAP systems, more specifically, free software implementation, OpenLDAP. During this time, I've discovered the vast possibilities presented by this environment: multiple uses, power, reliability, scalability, and many more benefits. But I've been involved in its dark side, especially regarding their documentation sparse, widely scattered, often outdated.

The purpose of this site is to help others sharing my experience and I also intend to continue learning of you.

Thanks for pay attention.
